channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hong Kong Arrests Jimmy Lai Under National Security Law
item.description: The pro-democracy figure is the most high-profile person detained under the sweeping legislation imposed by Beijing. “It’s hard to believe this is Hong Kong,” said a journalist.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May
item.media:description: Jimmy Lai, center, has long been a thorn in the side of the Chinese Communist Party for his support of the pro-democracy camp in Hong Kong.

item.title: Belarus’s Aleksandr Lukashenko Vows to Crush Election Protests
item.description: Violent clashes between the police and protesters erupted across Belarus on Monday after President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko declared victory in a vote widely dismissed as fraudulent.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Police officers detained demonstrators in Minsk, Belarus, on Monday during a protest the day after the country’s presidential election.

item.title: Mexico’s Coronavirus Struggle Worsened by Fear of Hospitals
item.description: A fear of hospitals is leading many Mexicans to delay treatment for coronavirus until it is too late for doctors to help them.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff and Paulina Villegas
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The family of Victor Bailón gathers at his grave at a cemetery in Tonanitla, Mexico.

item.title: A Push to Return U.K.’s ‘Motor City’ to Its Cycling Roots
item.description: Coventry can be forbidding for cyclists. But before it became Britain’s Detroit, the city was famed for making bicycles.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.media:description: Coventry’s cyclists aim to revive the city’s bike culture with a campaign involving health, the environment, the coronavirus pandemic — and history.

item.title: As U.S.-China Ties Deteriorate, Taiwan’s Importance Grows
item.description: The highest-level American visit to Taiwan in decades shows the island’s importance as ties between the United States and China deteriorate.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin

item.title: Lebanon’s Government Resigns Over Beirut Explosion
item.description: The cabinet stepped down as fury over a giant explosion last week in Beirut spurred new protests.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Lebanon, outside Parliament in downtown Beirut, on Monday.

item.title: Pints or Primers? U.K.’s Push to Open Schools May Force a Choice
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson calls it a “moral duty” to open Britain’s schools, but with cases already rising slightly, that might mean closing pubs and restaurants.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Pubs reopened for business in July, but experts are warning that they might be forced to shut down again if the government follows through on its plan to open schools at all levels this year.

item.title: England’s Flawed Virus Contact Tracing Will Be Revamped
item.description: After months of complaints about its centralized, privatized system, Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s government says resources will be diverted to local public health authorities.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.media:description: Changes to England’s contact tracing system were a recognition by the government that a centralized, privatized operation is falling short of what is needed.

item.title: Algerian Journalist Khaled Drareni Sentenced to Prison
item.description: The journalist Khaled Drareni was convicted after reporting on the Hirak protest movement, which forced the removal of the country’s longtime ruler, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, last year.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Khaled Drareni at a protest in Algiers, Algeria, in March. Mr. Drareni was convicted of “inciting an unarmed gathering” and “endangering national unity.”

item.title: Should Montreal Subway Honor Polarizing Priest or Jazz Genius?
item.description: A fight to rename a metro stop pits those who want to celebrate a revered Black musician against those who want to retain the name of a priest who espoused equal rights for Francophone Quebecers — and also anti-Semitism.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Naveed Hussain, outside the Lionel-Groulx metro station. “The metros and monuments in this city are irrelevant to our current times,” he said.

item.title: Live Coronavirus News: World Updates
item.description: The Trump administration is ordering schools on Native American reservations to reopen. California’s chief health officer has resigned.

item.title: Afghanistan to Release Last Taliban Prisoners, Removing Final Hurdle to Talks
item.description: The decision clears the way for the last of 5,000 insurgents to be freed. President Ashraf Ghani announced the release after convening an assembly of 3,000 representatives to seek their advice.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Fatima Faizi
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Taliban prisoners at Bagram Military Base in Afghanistan before being released, in late May.

item.title: Beirut Explosion Hit 3 Disparate Neighborhoods. Now They're United in Rage
item.description: The demands for a change in Lebanon’s leadership are growing louder.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A man slept outside destroyed apartments in the Quarantine neighborhood of Beirut, a city where the explosion last week killed over 150 people and left hundreds of thousands homeless.

item.title: 8 Dead After Attack in a Wildlife Reserve in Niger
item.description: French humanitarian workers, their Nigerien driver and a guide were killed, according to the authorities. The group was visiting an area known for its West African giraffes.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The group had traveled to Kouré reserve, which is home to the only remaining population of West African giraffes.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Lebanon resignations, Belarus protests, Champions League: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai

item.title: U.S. Contractor Knew of Explosive Material in Beirut Since at Least 2016
item.description: An American contractor spotted and reported the potential danger at least four years ago, but U.S. officials denied they were aware of the findings until last week, after the blast.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib and Ben Hubbard
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Last Tuesday, 2,750 tons of ammonium nitrate exploded, damaging buildings across a wide swath of central Beirut and killing more than 150 people.

item.title: State Dept. Says Report Defends Pompeo on Arms Sales. But It Finds Fault Over Mass Deaths.
item.description: The agency gave its interpretation of an inspector general’s report on Secretary of State Mike Pompeo pushing arms sales to Saudi Arabia and the U.A.E., but declined to release the findings.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Michael LaForgia
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo declared an “emergency” last year to push through $8.1 billon of arms sales.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Lebanon’s government, Jimmy Lai, Causeway Bay Books: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: Prime Minister Hassan Diab submits his resignation at the presidential palace in Baabda, Lebanon, on Monday.

item.title: Citrus Flavoring Is Weaponized Against Insect-Borne Diseases
item.description: The E.P.A. has approved nootkatone, which is found in cedars and grapefruit. It repels ticks, mosquitoes and other dangerous bugs for hours, but is safe enough to eat.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority
item.media:description: One proposed use is in soaps that people in tick-infested areas could shower with, repelling and possibly killing ticks that try to attach to them.

item.title: Biden’s Choice
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Ian Prasad Philbrick and Sanam Yar
item.media:description: Joe Biden at a campaign event in Wilmington, Del., at the end of July.

item.title: Beirut, Hong Kong, Belarus Elections: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Demonstrators filled the streets in Minsk, Belarus, after polling stations closed for the country’s presidential election.

item.title: Belarus Says Longtime Leader Is Re-elected in Vote Critics Call Rigged
item.description: A government exit poll said Aleksandr Lukashenko had won almost 80 percent of the vote. That triggered protests against the repressive regime, and a heavy police response.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Protesters running through the streets of Minsk on Sunday.

item.title: New Zealand, Beirut Protests, Fashion’s Future: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: People enjoying lunch in Christchurch, New Zealand, on Sunday.

item.title: Macron Urges World Leaders to Speed Aid to Lebanon After Explosions
item.description: The vow to accelerate help, made during a video call with other heads of state, comes amid furious demonstrations in Beirut against the Lebanese government.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France, center left with raised hand, toured Beirut on Thursday, just days after disaster struck.

item.title: At Least 97,000 Children in the U.S. Tested Positive in Last 2 Weeks of July
item.description: Trump’s unilateral economic relief actions come under fire. Ohio’s governor urges use of rapid tests, but with caution after his false positive.

item.title: How to Move Your Elephant During a Pandemic
item.description: After decades in captivity and a 1,700-mile road trip from Argentina into Brazil, an Asian elephant named Mara finally gained a chance to roam.
item.dc:creator: Sofía López Mañán and Brooke Jarvis
item.media:description: Mara at the Buenos Aires zoo. Her enclosure was built in 1904 to resemble a Hindu temple of elephants in Mumbai.

item.title: 2 Ex-Green Berets Sentenced to 20 Years for Venezuela Attack
item.description: Venezuelan prosecutors said the former Green Berets admitted to taking part in a failed attack aimed at overthrowing the country’s president.
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
United States Army Special Forces (Green Berets)
item.media:description: Members of a Venezuelan special forces unit standing guard after a failed incursion in May.

item.title: After Beirut Explosion, Protests Erupt as Lebanon's Anger Boils Over
item.description: The demonstrations were fueled by fury over the corruption and negligence of the country’s ruling elite. Security forces fired tear gas to push back the protesters.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Mona El-Naggar
item.media:description: Protesters clashed with security forces on Saturday in Beirut.

item.title: Air India Crash Investigators Focus On a Dangerous Runway and a Pilot’s Actions
item.description: As investigators sought the cause of a jetliner accident that killed 18 people, blame began to fall on the pilot and the hilltop runway.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Suhasini Raj and Shalini Venugopal Bhagat
item.media:description: The Air India Express flight skidded off the runway and down a hill after landing in Kozhikode, India.

item.title: Brazil Reaches Milestone of More Than 100,000 Covid-19 Deaths and 3 Million Cases
item.description: President Trump signed executive measures for pandemic relief as stimulus talks stalled. And Brazil reached two coronavirus milestones: more than 100,000 deaths and more than three million cases.

item.title: Hong Kong Officials Condemn and Mock Trump Administration Sanctions
item.description: Officials in Hong Kong targeted by new United States sanctions argued on Saturday that the move harmed American interests and would have little impact on them.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur
item.media:description: Hong Kong’s chief executive, Carrie Lam, said the Trump administration got her address wrong in the text of the new sanctions.

item.title: When Covid-19 Hit, Many Elderly Were Left to Die
item.description: Warnings had piled up for years that nursing homes were vulnerable. The pandemic sent them to the back of the line for equipment and care.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Matt Apuzzo, Monika Pronczuk and Mauricio Lima
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the Christalain nursing home in Brussels, at least 14 residents died from the coronavirus.

item.title: Near U.K.’s Busiest Port, Brexit Hopes Are Layered in Asphalt
item.description: A 27-acre site is being built to handle trucks amid fears that new trade rules will slow freight movement. It has been nicknamed the “Farage Garage” after the pro-Brexit campaigner Nigel Farage.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Kent countryside will house a sprawling center for checking freight trucks.

item.title: Unwanted Truths: Inside Trump’s Battles With U.S. Intelligence Agencies
item.description: Last year, intelligence officials gathered to write a classified report on Russia’s interest in the 2020 election. An investigation from the magazine uncovered what happened next.
item.dc:creator: Robert Draper
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
Office of the Director of National Intelligence
Trump-Ukraine Whistle-Blower Complaint and Impeachment Inquiry

item.title: As Lebanon Reels, Long-Awaited Hariri Assassination Verdicts Loom
item.description: A U.N.-backed court will soon pronounce verdicts in a 15-year-old bombing in Beirut that roiled the Middle East. But critics say the court’s protracted deliberations and huge expense have undermined its original purpose.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: The crater left by the bombing that targeted the motorcade of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri in Beirut, Lebanon, in 2005.

item.title: Coronavirus Spares Gaza, but Travel Restrictions Do Not
item.description: The blockaded Gaza Strip has not recorded any cases of community transmission of the coronavirus, but new restrictions on movement continue to make life difficult.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon and Iyad Abuheweila
item.media:credit: Fatima Shbair for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neveen Zanon, center, a resident of Rafah, has not been able to get permission to visit her father in Nablus, where he is suffering from esophageal cancer.

item.title: Bolivia Under Blockade as Protesters Choke Access to Cities
item.description: Six million people have been marooned by 70 roadblocks set up to protest the government’s response to the coronavirus and the postponement of the country’s general election.
item.dc:creator: María Silvia Trigo and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:description: A roadblock in El Alto, Bolivia, protesting the postponement of the general election.

item.title: Canada Has Placed Its First Vaccine Order, but Don’t Expect a ‘Silver Bullet’
item.description: Before the federal government announced an order for millions of doses of a still unproven vaccine, its top doctor sounded a note of caution.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.media:description: Canada has signed a vaccine supply contract with Morderna, based in Cambridge, Mass.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: New York schools move toward reopening.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga

item.title: Why the Coronavirus Is More Likely to ‘Superspread’ Than the Flu
item.description: Most people won’t spread the virus widely. The few who do are probably in the wrong place at the wrong time in their infection, new models suggest.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu
item.media:description: A recent study found that superspreading events typically occurred when a person was at the point in their infection when they were shedding large amounts of virus and doing so amid large numbers of people.

item.title: Brexit Behind Him, Boris Johnson Tries to Quiet Scotland’s Calls to Leave U.K.
item.description: Scottish polling shows a majority favor independence. The prime minister is concerned.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jeff J Mitchell
item.media:description: Scottish Nationalists demonstrating the arrival of Britain’s Treasury chief, Rishi Sunak, to the Isle of Bute. In an average of recent polls, 52.5 percent of people say they would vote for Scottish independence.

item.title: Ship Blamed in Beirut Explosion Hasn’t Sailed in 7 Years. We Found It.
item.description: The explosive material responsible for the Aug. 4 blast in Beirut was carried there by the ailing cargo ship Rhosus in 2013. Here’s what happened next.
item.dc:creator: Christoph Koettl and Drew Jordan

item.title: Mauritius Faces Environmental Crisis as Oil Spills From Grounded Ship
item.description: A Japanese-owned bulk carrier ran aground near the Indian Ocean island in late July, with nearly 4,000 tons of fuel oil and 200 tons of diesel on board. And now its hull has cracked.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Dev Ramkhelawon/L'Express Maurice via Agence France-Presse
item.media:description: The Wakashio bulk carrier ran aground near Blue Bay Marine Park in southeast Mauritius.

item.title: The Simple Joys of Tamarind
item.description: Sweet, sour and tender under its brittle shell, the fruit’s pulp is equally at home in desserts and savory dishes.
item.dc:creator: Nik Sharma
item.media:credit: Nik Sharma for The New York Times (Photography and Styling)
item.media:description: When working with tamarind fruit pods, make sure they’re unripe, which ensures a stronger degree of sourness.

item.title: Pompeo Warned Russia Against Bounties on U.S. Troops in Afghanistan
item.description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is said to have sternly discussed payouts and red lines in a telephone call with Sergey V. Lavrov, Russia’s foreign minister.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Eric Schmitt
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Jim Lo Scalzo
item.media:description: The warning from Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is the first publicly known rebuke from a senior American official to Russia over the bounties program.

item.title: Lebanon Faces Humanitarian Crisis After Beirut Explosion, U.N. Says
item.description: The United Nations warning came as President Michel Aoun said the investigation into the deadly explosion in Beirut would examine if “external interference” played a role.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Waiting for food and aid distribution in downtown Beirut on Thursday.

item.title: Air India Flight Skids and Cracks in Half
item.description: The plane, a Boeing 737, had been returning from Dubai when it skidded off a rain-soaked runway in the southern state of Kerala. The airline said 17 people had died.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:description: Rescue workers searching for survivors from the remains of the crash site at Calicut International Airport.

item.title: Trump Administration Imposes Sanctions Against Chinese Officials for Hong Kong Crackdown
item.description: The sanctions are the first punishments brought against officials in China and Hong Kong for suppressing pro-democracy protests.
item.dc:creator: Pranshu Verma and Edward Wong
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pro-democracy protest in July in Hong Kong. A new national security law that Beijing imposed on Hong Kong grants expansive powers to security agencies.

item.title: Aleksandr Lukashenko Increasingly in Peril as Belarus Election Nears
item.description: For 26 years, Aleksandr G. Lukashenko has ruled Belarus as if it were his personal fief. In his sixth presidential election, the result is not in doubt, but he is being challenged like never before.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: An opposition rally in Minsk, Belarus, last week.

item.title: A Warming World
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: Sanam Yar and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:credit: KC Nwakalor for The New York Times
item.media:description: Miracle, a 1-year-old girl in Obrikom, Nigeria.

item.title: Trump Vows to Issue Executive Orders if Coronavirus Relief Talks Collapse
item.description: New York’s governor said schools could reopen for in-person instruction, but he left the details up to the districts. Africa surpasses a million confirmed cases, though the real number may be higher.

item.title: For P.O.W., Landmark Verdict Against North Korea Is Long-Overdue Justice
item.description: A former South Korean soldier may never see a penny of the $17,600 awarded by a court last month. But the verdict set a precedent for thousands of others seeking to hold the North and Kim Jong-un accountable for human rights violations.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Woohae Cho for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. Han in his apartment in Pyeongtaek, South Korea, this month. He was captured by the Chinese Army during the Korean War and was forced to work in coal mines as a prisoner of war for decades.

item.title: Beijing Launches Another Demolition Drive, This Time in Its Bucolic Suburbs
item.description: The authorities have moved to demolish hundreds of homes in the hills near the Great Wall that were once a sign of China’s rising prosperity.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Villas slated for demolition in Wayaocun, on the northwest fringe of Beijing, last week.

item.title: Álvaro Uribe’s Detention Deepens Colombia’s Divisions
item.description: Colombia’s most powerful politician is now under house arrest, drawing the country back into the pitched political battle it had been trying to overcome for years.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in the streets of Medellín demonstrated their support for former president Álvaro Uribe after the Colombian Supreme Court ordered him to be detained.

item.title: Smile, Australia. Look at What’s Flourishing Despite the Pandemic.
item.description: As we rush into nature, books and fresher food, there are signs of a healthier existence beginning to emerge.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Michaela Skovranova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Underwater with the spearos near Manly.

item.title: Mumbai Finally Puts Female Figures on Traffic Lights
item.description: At many crossings, India’s largest city replaced male stick figures with icons in triangular dresses. But critics say the move does little to address an entrenched gender divide.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.category: Traffic and Parking Signals and Signs
item.media:credit: Prarthna Singh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mumbai installed 240 pedestrian signals that replaced male stick figures with female silhouettes along a stretch of road in the Dadar neighborhood.

item.title: Beirut, Coronavirus, TikTok Restrictions: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France visiting the Gemmayzeh neighborhood of Beirut on Thursday.

item.title: Sri Lanka Election Hands Rajapaksa Family a Bigger Slice of Control
item.description: President Gotabaya Rajapaksa’s party clinched the majority of seats in Parliament, aiming to amend the Constitution and expand presidential powers. Rights groups are concerned.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:credit: Ishara S. Kodikara/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Sri Lanka’s prime minister, Mahinda Rajapaksa, left, and his brother, President Gotabaya Rajapaksa, on the front page of a newspaper after parliamentary elections in Colombo, Sri Lanka, on Friday.

item.title: Paramedic Who Died in Beirut Explosion Is a Symbol of Lebanon’s Grief
item.description: Sahar Fares, 27, was planning her wedding. Instead, her family held her funeral after she died in the blast that tore through the city.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.media:description: Sahar Fares, 24, was one of at least 137 killed by the massive explosion that leveled most of Beirut Port on Tuesday.
